name: ad
content:
ad

noun
 
 
/æd/
 
/æd/
(British English also advert)
(both informal)
(also advertisement)
jump to other results
  1. a notice, picture or film telling people about a product, job or service
    • The TV ads were first run last year.
    • They've produced an ad for a new chocolate bar.
    • We put an ad on a classifieds website.
    • A $10 million TV ad campaign
    • an ad agency
    see also attack ad, banner ad
    Extra Examples
    • A lot of claims are made in the ad.
    • She took out a full-page ad in a women's magazine.
    • TV ads for cars
    • The ad appeared on all major channels.
    • You can put your own small ads in local papers.
    • He was scanning the classified ads.
    • You may have seen the full-page ads that we ran in the New York Times.
    Topics TV, radio and newsb1, Businessb1
    Word Originmid 19th cent.: abbreviation.
See ad in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ad

name: AD
content:
AD

abbreviation
 
/ˌeɪ ˈdiː/
 
/ˌeɪ ˈdiː/
(also A.D. especially in US English)
jump to other results
  1. used in the Christian calendar to show a particular number of years since the year when Christ was believed to have been born (from Latin ‘Anno Domini’)
    • in (the year) AD 55
    • in 55 AD
    • in the fifth century AD
    compare AH, BC, BCE, CE
    Culture the calendarthe calendarBritain and the US follow the Gregorian calendar, which replaced the Roman Julian calendar in 1752. The year is divided into 12 months, with 30 or 31 days in each month, except February, which has 28 days. An extra day is added to February every fourth year, called a leap year, to keep the calendar in time with the moon. A well-known verse helps people remember how many days there are in each month:“Thirty days hath September,April, June and November.All the rest have thirty-one,Excepting February alone,Which hath twenty-eight days clear,and twenty-nine in each leap year.”The calendar year starts on 1 January, New Year’s Day. The number of each year (2003, 2004, etc.) represents the number of years that have passed since the birth of Jesus Christ. The year 2000 marked the end of the second millennium (= a period of 1 000 years) since Christ was born. The years before Christ are described as BC (= before Christ), for example, 55 BC, or BCE (= before the Common Era). AD (Latin Anno Domini, meaning ‘in the year of the Lord’) or CE (= Common Era) are put before or after the date for the years after Christ's birth, for example, AD 44 or 44 AD, but they are not used with years after about 200 AD. Some cultural and religious groups use different calendars: the year 2000 in the Gregorian calendar began during the year 5760 in the Jewish calendar, 1420 in the Islamic calendar and 1921 in the Hindu calendar.The academic year used by schools and colleges in Britain runs from September to July, with short holidays at Christmas and in the spring and a long summer vacation. In the US the academic year runs from August or September to May or June. Many business companies have a financial year (= a period of accounting) that runs from April to the following March. The tax year in the US is the same as the calendar year but the tax year in Britain begins on 5 April. The reason is that in the Middle Ages the calendar year began on 25 March, not 1 January. When the Gregorian Calendar was introduced, an adjustment was needed and 11 days were removed from September 1752. To avoid being accused of collecting a full year's taxes in a short year, the government made the end of the 1752-3 tax year 4 April.Many festivals are celebrated during the year. Christmas and Easter are the main Christian festivals. Jews remember Passover and Yom Kippur. Ramadan, a month of fasting (= not eating during the day), and Eid ul-Fitr are celebrated by Muslims. Diwali, the Hindu festival of light, takes place in October or November, and the Chinese celebrate their new year in January or February. Special occasions such as Bonfire Night in Britain and Thanksgiving in the US are enjoyed by almost everyone.
    Topics Timec1, Historyc1
Check pronunciation: AD

name: advert
content:
advert

noun
 
/ˈædvɜːt/
 
/ˈædvɜːrt/
 (British English, informal)
(also advertisement British and North American English)
jump to other results
  1. (also ad informal)
     a notice, picture or film telling people about a product, job or service
    • the adverts on television
    • I fast-forwarded through the adverts.
    • When the adverts came on I got up to put the kettle on.
    Extra Examples
    • A lot of claims are made in the advert.
    • How can I block those annoying pop-up adverts?
    • I put an advert in the local newspaper.
    • She took out a full-page advert in a magazine.
    • The advert appeared in ‘The Guardian’.
    • The paper ran our advert last week.
    • an advert for jeans
    Topics TV, radio and newsa2, Businessa2
  2. advert for something an example of something that shows its good qualities
    3. Word Originmid 19th cent.: abbreviation.
Check pronunciation: advert

name: ad hoc
content:
ad hoc

adjective
 
/ˌæd ˈhɒk/
 
/ˌæd ˈhɑːk/
(from Latin)
jump to other results
  1. arranged or happening when necessary and not planned in advance
    • an ad hoc meeting to deal with the problem
    • The meetings will be held on an ad hoc basis.
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryAd hoc is used with these nouns:
    • basis
    • committee
    • explanation
    • …
    See full entry
    Word OriginLatin, literally ‘to this’.
See ad hoc in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee ad hoc in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: ad hoc

name: ad hoc
content:
ad hoc

adverb
 
/ˌæd ˈhɒk/
 
/ˌæd ˈhɑːk/
(from Latin)
jump to other results
  1. in a way that is arranged or happens when necessary and is not planned in advance
    • The tribunals operated ad hoc and were dissolved when the work was concluded.
Check pronunciation: ad hoc

name: ad lib
content:
ad lib

adverb
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
jump to other results
  1. if you give a speech or performance ad lib, you do it without preparing or practising
    • She delivered her lines ad lib.
    Topics Film and theatrec2
Check pronunciation: ad lib

name: ad lib
content:
ad lib

noun
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
jump to other results
  1. something that you say in a speech or a performance that you have not prepared or practised
    • The speech was full of ad libs.
    Topics Film and theatrec2
Check pronunciation: ad lib

name: ad-lib
content:
ad-lib

verb
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
 [intransitive, transitive]
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they ad-lib
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
he / she / it ad-libs
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbz/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbz/
past simple ad-libbed
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbd/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbd/
past participle ad-libbed
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbd/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbd/
-ing form ad-libbing
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbɪŋ/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪbɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. to say something in a speech or a performance that you have not prepared or practised synonym improvise
    • She abandoned her script and began ad-libbing.
    • ad-lib something I lost my notes and had to ad-lib the whole speech.
    • He ad-libbed his way through the meeting.
    Topics Film and theatrec2
    Word Originearly 19th cent. (as an adverb): abbreviation of ad libitum.
Check pronunciation: ad-lib

name: ad-lib
content:
ad-lib

adjective
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
 
/ˌæd ˈlɪb/
jump to other results
  1. an ad-lib speech or performance has not been prepared or practisedTopics Film and theatrec2
Check pronunciation: ad-lib

name: small ad
content:
small ad

noun
 
/ˈsmɔːl æd/
 
/ˈsmɔːl æd/
 (British English)
(also classified, classified ad, classified advertisement)
(all British and North American English)
(North American English also want ad)
[usually plural]
jump to other results
  1. a small advertisement in a newspaper or on a website, placed in a section according to its subject, that is placed by a person or small company who wants to buy or sell something, find or offer a job, etc.Topics TV, radio and newsc2, Businessc2
Check pronunciation: small ad

name: want ad
content:
want ad

noun
 
/ˈwɒnt æd/
 
/ˈwɑːnt æd/
 (North American English)
(also classified ad, classified, classified advertisements (all British and North American English))
(British English also small ad)
[usually plural]
jump to other results
  1. a small advertisement in a newspaper or on a website, placed in a section according to its subject, that is placed by a person or small company who wants to buy or sell something, find or offer a job, etc.Topics TV, radio and newsc2, Businessc2
Check pronunciation: want ad

name: attack ad
content:
attack ad

noun
 
/əˈtæk æd/
 
/əˈtæk æd/
jump to other results
  1. an advertisement that promotes a particular politician or political party by presenting the opposition in a negative way
    • Her political opponents ran a series of attack ads against her, which aired on TV and radio.
    Topics Politicsc2
Check pronunciation: attack ad

name: banner ad
content:
banner ad

noun
 
/ˈbænər æd/
 
/ˈbænər æd/
jump to other results
  1. an advertisement across the top or bottom or down the side of a page on the internetTopics Phones, email and the internetc2, Businessc2
See banner ad in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: banner ad

name: ad blocker
content:
ad blocker

noun
 
/ˈæd blɒkə(r)/
 
/ˈæd blɑːkər/
jump to other results
  1. a piece of software that removes the advertisements from a web page when you view it
    • Widespread use of ad blockers could pose a threat to the way many websites are currently funded.
    Topics Phones, email and the internetc2
Check pronunciation: ad blocker

name: ad hominem
content:
ad hominem

adjective, adverb
 
/ˌæd ˈhɒmɪnem/
 
/ˌæd ˈhɑːmɪnem/
 (from Latin, formal)
jump to other results
  1. directed against a person’s character rather than their argument
    • an ad hominem attack
    Topics Opinion and argumentc2
    Word OriginLatin, literally ‘to the person’.
See ad hominem in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ad hominem

name: ad nauseam
content:
ad nauseam

adverb
 
/ˌæd ˈnɔːziəm/
 
/ˌæd ˈnɔːziəm/
(from Latin)
jump to other results
  1. if a person says or does something ad nauseam, they say or do it again and again so that it becomes boring or annoying
    • Sports commentators repeat the same phrases ad nauseam.
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryAd nauseam is used with these verbs:
    • repeat
    See full entry
    Word OriginLatin, literally ‘to sickness’.
See ad nauseam in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ad nauseam

name: ad valorem
content:
ad valorem

adjective, adverb
 
/ˌæd vəˈlɔːrem/
 
/ˌæd vəˈlɔːrem/
(finance)
jump to other results
  1. (of a tax) according to the estimated value of the goods being taxed
    Word OriginLatin, ‘according to the value’.
See ad valorem in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ad valorem

name: personal ad
content:
personal ad

noun
 
/ˈpɜːsənl æd/
 
/ˈpɜːrsənl æd/
jump to other results
  1. a private advertisement in a newspaper, etc., especially from somebody who is looking for a romantic or sexual partner
See personal ad in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: personal ad

name: ad infinitum
content:
ad infinitum

adverb
 
/ˌæd ɪnfɪˈnaɪtəm/
 
/ˌæd ɪnfɪˈnaɪtəm/
(from Latin)
jump to other results
  1. without ever coming to an end; again and again
    • You cannot stay here ad infinitum without paying rent.
    • The problem would be repeated ad infinitum.
    Word OriginLatin, literally ‘to infinity’.
See ad infinitum in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ad infinitum

name: reductio ad absurdum
content:
reductio ad absurdum

noun
 
/rɪˌdʌktiəʊ æd æbˈsɜːdəm/
 
/rɪˌdʌktiəʊ æd æbˈsɜːrdəm/
[uncountable, countable] (from Latin, philosophy)
jump to other results
  1. a method of proving that something is not true by showing that its result is not logical or sensible
    Word OriginLatin, literally ‘reduction to the absurd’.
See reductio ad absurdum in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: reductio ad absurdum

name: AD
content:
AD

abbreviation
 
/ˌeɪ ˈdiː/
 
/ˌeɪ ˈdiː/
(also A.D. especially in US English)
jump to other results
  1. used in the Christian calendar to show a particular number of years since the year when Christ was believed to have been born (from Latin ‘Anno Domini’)
    • in (the year) AD 55
    • in 55 AD
    • in the fifth century AD
    compare AH, BC, BCE, CE
    Culture the calendarthe calendarBritain and the US follow the Gregorian calendar, which replaced the Roman Julian calendar in 1752. The year is divided into 12 months, with 30 or 31 days in each month, except February, which has 28 days. An extra day is added to February every fourth year, called a leap year, to keep the calendar in time with the moon. Diwali, the Hindu festival of light, takes place in October or November, and the Chinese celebrate their new year in January or February. Special occasions such as Bonfire Night in Britain and Thanksgiving in the US are enjoyed by almost everyone.
